revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Patton Oswalt | image = Patton Oswalt by Gage Skidmore 3 (cropped).jpg | caption = Oswalt at 2017 [[San Diego Comic-Con]] | birth_name = Patton Peter Oswalt | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1969|1|27}} | birth_place = [[Portsmouth, Virginia]], U.S. | medium = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand-up]], [[television]], [[film]] | alma_mater = [[College of William & Mary]] | active = 1988{{ndash}}present | genre = [[Observational comedy]], [[black comedy]], [[surreal humour|surreal humor]], [[insult comedy]], [[sarcasm]], [[satire]] | subject = [[Popular culture]], [[news|current events]], [[politics]], [[religion]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Michelle McNamara]]
|September 24, 2005|April 21, 2016|reason=died}}
{{marriage|[[Meredith Salenger]]
|November 4, 2017}} | children = 1 | relatives = [[Matt Oswalt]] (brother) | website = {{Official website}} }} '''Patton Peter Oswalt''' (born January 27, 1969) is an American stand-up comedian, actor, voice actor and writer known for roles such as Spencer Olchin in the sitcom ''[[The King of Queens]]'' (1998–2007), voicing Remy in the film ''[[Ratatouille (film)|Ratatouille]]'' (2007), co-starring alongside [[Charlize Theron]] in ''[[Young Adult (film)|Young Adult]]'' (2011), and playing multiple identical brothers, [[Eric Koenig|the Koenigs]], on ''[[Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.]]'' (2014–17). Oswalt has appeared in six stand-up specials and won a [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Variety Special]] and a [[Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album]] for his [[Netflix]] special ''Patton Oswalt: Talking for Clapping'' (2016). Oswalt made his acting debut in the ''[[Seinfeld]]'' episode "[[The Couch (Seinfeld)|The Couch]]" and has since also appeared in the superhero film ''[[Blade: Trinity]]'' (2004) and starred in the comedy-drama film ''[[Big Fan]]'' (2009) and the comedy series ''[[The Heart, She Holler]]'' (2011–2014). He currently narrates the sitcom ''[[The Goldbergs (2013 TV series)|The Goldbergs]]'' (2013–present) as the adult [[Adam F. Goldberg]], voiced male Jesse in both seasons of the video game ''[[Minecraft: Story Mode]]'', stars in the [[Mystery Science Theater 3000#Revival (2017%E2%80%93present)|2017 revival]] of ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'', voices the title character in the crime comedy series ''[[Happy! (TV series)|Happy!]]'' (2017–present) and co-stars as Principal Ralph Durbin on the sitcom ''[[A.P. Bio]]'' (2018–present). ==Early life== Oswalt was born January 27,Abernathy, Samantha (January 7, 2012). [http://chicagoist.com/2012/01/27/one_for_the_road_have_a_kfc_bowl_fo.php "One For The Road: Have A KFC Bowl For Patton Oswalt's Birthday"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120128004442/http://chicagoist.com/2012/01/27/one_for_the_road_have_a_kfc_bowl_fo.php |date=January 28, 2012 }}. [[Gothamist]].Tobey, Matt [http://ccinsider.comedycentral.com/2009/01/27/happy-birthday-patton-oswalt "Happy Birthday, Patton Oswalt!"]. [[Comedy Central|CC: Insider]]. Retrieved May 30, 2012.{{Dead link|date=January 2017}} 1969,[http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/patton-oswalt/190729 "Patton Oswalt: Biography, Latest News & Videos"]. ''[[TV Guide]]''. Retrieved May 30, 2012. in [[Portsmouth, Virginia]], the son of Carla (née Runfola) and Larry J. Oswalt, a career [[United States Marine Corps]] officer.{{cite news|title=Michelle McNamara, Patton Oswalt|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 25, 2005|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9905E2DE1430F936A1575AC0A9639C8B63}} He was named after General [[George S. Patton]].{{cite web|author=Wait Wait...Don't Tell Me! |url=https://www.npr.org/2011/10/15/141370178/comedian-patton-oswalt-plays-not-my-job |title=Comedian Patton Oswalt Plays Not My Job |publisher=NPR |date=October 15, 2011 |accessdate=April 2, 2012}} He has one younger brother, [[Matt Oswalt]], a comedy writer best known for the YouTube web series ''Puddin'''. While he was a [[Military brat (U.S. subculture)|military brat]], his family lived in [[Ohio]] and [[Tustin, California]], before settling in [[Sterling, Virginia|Sterling]], Virginia.{{cite book | title=Zombie Spaceship Wasteland | author=Oswalt, Patton | year=2011 | publisher=Scribner | page=6 | isbn=978-1-4391-4908-9}} He is a 1987 graduate of [[Broad Run High School]] in [[Ashburn, Virginia|Ashburn]], Virginia, and subsequently graduated from [[The College of William & Mary]], where he majored in English{{cite news|last=Chaney|first=Jen|url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2011-12-15/lifestyle/35288343_1_matt-freehauf-patton-oswalt-class-clown|title=Patton Oswalt gets philosophical, but he's still funny|date=December 15, 2011|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=December 12, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104153228/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2011-12-15/lifestyle/35288343_1_matt-freehauf-patton-oswalt-class-clown|archivedate=November 4, 2013|df=mdy-all}} and was initiated into the Alpha Theta Chapter of the [[Phi Kappa Tau]] Fraternity.{{cite web|url=http://www.phikappatau.org/about-pkt/phi-kappa-tau-hall-of-fame.html|title=Phi Kappa Tau Hall of Fame|publisher=phikappatau.org|accessdate=December 12, 2012}} ==Career== Oswalt began performing [[stand-up comedy]] on July 18, 1988.{{cite web|last1=Oswalt|first1=Patton|title=Patton Oswalt Goes Undercover on Reddit, Twitter & Wikipedia|url=https://video.gq.com/watch/actually-me-patton-oswalt-goes-undercover-on-reddit-twitter-wikipedia?c=series|website=GQ Videos|publisher=CONDÉ NAST|accessdate=8 February 2018|language=en|format=video|date=1 February 2018|quote='Oswalt first began performing stand-up comedy in the late 80s or early 90s'{{emdash}}late 80s{{emdash}}'by his own reckoning'. I know the exact date, Wikipedia. I've said it in a million interviews. 'My own reckoning'{{emdash}}what did I, suffer a head injury? I started July 18th, 1988. I'm not some weird Norse poet. 'Ah, by my reckoning, it was a stormy night. I was out on'{{emdash}}No! July 18th, 1988. 'By my own reckoning', good Lord. Is [this] a [[Cormac McCarthy]] novel? |at=05:10}} After writing for ''[[MADtv]]'' and starring in his own 1996 comedy special for [[HBO]], he went on to garner notable roles in films and television shows.{{cite web|url=http://www.tribute.ca/people/patton-oswalt/18696/|title=Patton Oswalt biography and filmography|work=[[Tribute (magazine)|Tribute]]|accessdate=September 3, 2013}} His most prominent and long-running role was as [[Spence Olchin]] on ''[[The King of Queens]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/22/patton-oswalt-stands-perfectly-still-on-king-of-queens_n_1108501.html|title=Patton Oswalt Pranks 'King of Queens' By Standing Perfectly Still For Entire Scene (VIDEO)|work=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=September 3, 2013|first=Ross|last=Luippold|date=November 22, 2011}} His first starring film role was as the voice of Remy, the lead character in the 2007 [[Pixar]] film ''[[Ratatouille (film)|Ratatouille]]''. He has also appeared in smaller roles in such films as ''[[Magnolia (film)|Magnolia]]'' and ''[[22 Jump Street]]''. His influences include [[Jonathan Winters]], [[Richard Pryor]],{{cite web|url=http://aspecialthing.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?t=1465 |title=aspecialthing.com :: View topic – THE AST INTERVIEW: PATTON OSWALT |publisher=Web.archive.org |accessdate=September 24, 2010 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071013165258/http://aspecialthing.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?t=1465 |archivedate = October 13, 2007}} [[Emo Philips]], [[Blaine Capatch]], [[Bill Hicks]], [[Bobcat Goldthwait]], [[Sam Kinison]], [[Steve Martin]],{{cite web|url=http://aspecialthing.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?t=1465 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013165258/http://aspecialthing.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?t=1465 |archivedate=October 13, 2007 |title=The AST Interview: Patton Oswalt |publisher=Web.archive.org |accessdate=February 28, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://aspecialthing.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?t=1465 |title=Patton Oswalt: The AST Interview |accessdate=August 19, 2010 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071013165258/http://aspecialthing.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?t=1465 |archivedate = October 13, 2007}} and [[Louis C.K.]] Oswalt wrote the comic book story "JLA: Welcome to the Working Week", a backup story in ''[[Batman]]'' #600; a story for ''Dwight T. Albatross's The Goon Noir #01'' and a story for ''Masks: Too Hot for TV''.{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=1987|title=A Look Inside: 'King of Queens' Patton Oswalt talks 'JLA: Workweek' – Comic Book Resources|work=[[Comic Book Resources]]|accessdate=September 3, 2013}} Expanding his voice artist repertoire, he began voicing the villainous character "Tobey" on [[PBS Kids GO!]] series ''[[WordGirl]]'' in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/events/patton-oswalt-to-host-39th-annual-annie-awards/|title=Patton Oswalt to Host 39th Annual Annie Awards – Animation Magazine|accessdate=September 3, 2013}} He also appeared on the ''[[Comedy Central Roast of William Shatner]]''. In August 2007, he appeared on the ''[[Comedy Central Roast of Flavor Flav]]''.{{cite web|url=http://ca.askmen.com/celebs/men/entertainment/patton-oswalt/|title=Patton Oswalt – AskMen|work=[[AskMen]]|accessdate=September 3, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222195302/http://ca.askmen.com/celebs/men/entertainment/patton-oswalt/|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}} In 2007, he appeared on an episode of ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'', "[[The Original Fry Cook]]", as Jim. In 2008 Oswalt moderated a reunion panel of the ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'' cast at the [[San Diego Comic-Con International]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tor.com/blogs/2008/08/mst3katsdcc|title=Exclusive interview with Jim Mallon, Trace Beaulieu, and Joel Hodgson of Mystery Science Theatre 3000 |work=[[Tor Books]]|accessdate=September 3, 2013}} In 2009, Oswalt played Paul Aufiero, the leading role in [[Robert D. Siegel]]'s 2009 directorial debut, ''[[Big Fan]]''. He was to star in a 2010 Broadway revival of ''[[Lips Together, Teeth Apart]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/135469-Megan-Mullally-and-Patton-Oswalt-Will-Have-Lips-Together-Teeth-Apart-on-Broadway |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091226052012/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/135469-Megan-Mullally-and-Patton-Oswalt-Will-Have-Lips-Together-Teeth-Apart-on-Broadway |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 26, 2009 |title=Megan Mullally and Patton Oswalt Will Have Lips Together, Teeth Apart on Broadway |first=Kenneth |last=Jones |date=December 22, 2009 |work=[[Playbill]] |accessdate=March 10, 2010 |df= }} However, the show was postponed then eventually canceled due to [[Megan Mullally]]'s departure from the production when the director denied her request to replace Oswalt due to his lack of stage experience.Healy, Patrick.[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/26/theater/26mullally.html McNally Play Is Postponed After Mullally’s Departure"]''The New York Times'', March 25, 2010 He starred in the Showtime drama ''[[The United States of Tara]]'' as Neil, an employee of Four Winds Landscaping.{{cite web|url=http://www.sho.com/sho/video/series#/video/titles/13831/patton-oswalt-on-united-states-of-tara |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120422041922/http://www.sho.com/sho/video/series |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 22, 2012 |title=Showtime : Video : Series : Featured |work=[[Showtime (TV channel)|Showtime]] |accessdate=September 3, 2013 |df= }} He also provided the voice of Thrasher, a robot protagonist from the Cartoon Network show ''[[Robotomy]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/tv/cn-premieres-robotomy-on-oct-25-2/|title=CN Premieres Robotomy on Oct. 25 – Animation Magazine|accessdate=September 3, 2013}} In 2011, Oswalt released the book ''Zombie Spaceship Wasteland''.{{cite book |title=Zombie Spaceship Wasteland: A Book by Patton Oswalt |first=Patton |last=Oswalt |isbn=9781439149096| publisher=[[Charles Scribner's Sons]] |year=2011}} In November 2011, Oswalt played the role of Hurlan Heartshe in the surrealist comedy miniseries ''[[The Heart, She Holler]]'' on [[Cartoon Network]]'s late-night programming block, [[Adult Swim]]. Also in November 2011, Oswalt appeared in ''[[A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas]]''. In December 2011, Oswalt played Matt Freehauf in [[Jason Reitman]]'s black comedy ''[[Young Adult (film)|Young Adult]]''. In 2012, he originated the role of Billy Stanhope on ''[[Two and a Half Men]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/02/28/two-and-a-half-men-patton-oswalt-partner-video_n_1305846.html|title='Two and a Half Men': Patton Oswalt Plays Walden's Bitter Old Business Partner (VIDEO)|work=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=September 3, 2013|first=Jason|last=Hughes|date=February 28, 2012}} As of September 2013, Oswalt narrates the TV series ''[[The Goldbergs (2013 TV series)|The Goldbergs]]''.{{cite news|author=Brian Lowry TV Columnist @blowryontv |url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/reviews/the-goldbergs-tv-review-1200613772/ |title=TV Review: ‘The Goldbergs’ |work=Variety |date=September 17, 2013 |accessdate=January 18, 2014}} He also had a recurring role as Constable Bob Sweeney in the fourth season of the FX series ''[[Justified (TV series)|Justified]]''. Patton played the role of Agent Koenig on the TV series ''[[Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.]]'' He later appeared in separate episodes as brothers [[Eric Koenig#Television|Eric]] and Billy Koenig. He continued to appear in the second season as Billy and a third brother named Sam. In January 2015, Oswalt's memoir ''Silver Screen Fiend: Learning About Life from an Addiction to Film'' was published by [[Simon & Schuster]]. He also voiced the male version of Jesse in ''[[Minecraft: Story Mode]]'', which was released in October 2015. In November 2015, Oswalt was announced to be the second "Mad" to appear in the reboot of ''Mystery Science Theater 3000'', as the son of [[Frank Conniff]]'s character [[TV's Frank]].{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/mst3k/bringbackmst3k/posts/1430238|title=Bring Back MYSTERY SCIENCE THEATER 3000 by Joel Hodgson — Kickstarter|work=[[Kickstarter]]}}{{cite news | last=Rife | first=Katie | date= November 30, 2015 | title=Patton Oswalt is TV’s Son of TV's Frank on the new ''Mystery Science Theater 3000'' | url=http://www.avclub.com/article/patton-oswalt-tvs-son-tvs-frank-new-mystery-scienc-229058 | publisher=''[[The A.V. Club]]'' | access-date=July 22, 2016}} Oswalt had a voice over role in [[science fiction film|science fiction]] [[comedy film]] ''[[Sorry to Bother You (film)|Sorry to Bother You]]'',{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/sorry-to-bother-you-movie-danny-glover-david-cross-patton-oswalt-boots-riley-1202136106/|title=Danny Glover, David Cross And Patton Oswalt Join 'Sorry To Bother You'|last=Busch|first=Anita|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date= July 26, 2017|access-date=May 19, 2018}} which was released in theaters on July 6, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/watch-lakeith-stanfield-in-wild-sorry-to-bother-you-trailer-w520411|title=Watch Lakeith Stanfield Make Millions With 'White Voice' in Wild 'Sorry to Bother You' Trailer|last=Blistein|first=Jon|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date= May 17, 2018|access-date=May 19, 2018}} Oswalt is to star in ''[[The Secret Life of Pets 2]]'', where he is the replacement actor for the film's protagonist Max, replacing [[Louis C.K.]] ===Stand-up comedy=== [[File:Patton Oswalt by Gage Skidmore 2 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Patton Oswalt at the 2010 [[San Diego Comic-Con International]]]] Oswalt's stand-up comedy covers topics ranging from pop culture frivolity, such as comic book supervillains and 1980s [[glam metal]], to deeper social issues like American excess, materialism, foreign policy and religion. He also discusses his [[atheism]] in his stand-up. On February 28, 2009, Oswalt recorded his third comedy album at the Lisner Auditorium at [[George Washington University]] in Washington D.C. It premiered on [[Comedy Central]] as ''Patton Oswalt: My Weakness is Strong'' on August 23, 2009, and was released on DVD August 25, 2009.The date of the DVD release was mentioned during commercial breaks the night of the special's Comedy Central premiere on August 23, 2009. In November 2009, an animated video of Patton's take on [[NewSong|New Song]]'s [[The Christmas Shoes (song)|Christmas Shoes]] was posted on [[YouTube]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iq10bz3PxyY|title=Patton Oswalt - Christmas Shoes|first=|last=billybobjomes|date=November 24, 2009|publisher=|via=YouTube}} The track isn't found on any albums. The audio is claimed to be recorded at [[Lisner Auditorium]] in Washington DC.{{Cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/a-patton-oswalt-christmas-35764|title=A Patton Oswalt Christmas|date=2009-11-24|access-date=2016-07-14}} Oswalt's album, ''Patton Oswalt: Finest Hour'', was released on September 19, 2011. The extended and uncensored DVD of this special was released in April 2012, a few days after its television premiere on Comedy Central.{{cite news|last=Hartlaub|first=Peter|title=Sf gate – DVD review: 'Finest Hour' by Patton Oswalt|url=http://www.sfgate.com/movies/article/DVD-review-Finest-Hour-by-Patton-Oswalt-3549822.php|work=San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=November 8, 2012|date=May 13, 2012}}{{cite web|last=L. Ray|first=Austin|title=Patton Oswalt Finest Hour special review|url=http://www.thespittake.com/2012/04/24/patton-oswalt-finest-hour-comedy-central/|publisher=The Spit Take|accessdate=April 9, 2013}} Oswalt's comedy special ''[[Patton Oswalt: Tragedy Plus Comedy Equals Time|Tragedy Plus Comedy Equals Time]]'' was to be released on January 16, 2014, via online movie streaming website [[Epix]] but was pushed back by the company for unknown reasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.nerdist.com/2014/01/patton-oswalts-tragedy-plus-comedy-equals-time-airs-on-epix-and-twitter-sort-of/|title=Patton Oswalt’s TRAGEDY PLUS COMEDY EQUALS TIME Airs on Epix (and Twitter, Sort Of)|work=Nerdist}} However, it did premiere on [[Comedy Central]] on April 6 and became available for purchase on April 8 in both DVD and CD format.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/03/17/patton-oswalt-tragedy-plus-comedy-equals-time-to-premiere-sunday-april-6-on-comedy-central/245607/|title=‘Patton Oswalt: Tragedy Plus Comedy Equals Time’ to Premiere Sunday, April 6 on Comedy Central|work=TV By The Numbers by zap2it.com}} Oswalt's comedy special ''Talking for Clapping'' was released on [[Netflix]] on April 22, 2016.{{cite web|last=Halcombe|first=Don|title=Netflix Announces Premiere Dates for early 2016 Slate of Original Stand-up Comedy Specials|url=https://media.netflix.com/en/press-releases/netflix-announces-premiere-dates-for-early-2016-slate-of-original-stand-up-comedy-specials|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160223180507/https://media.netflix.com/en/press-releases/netflix-announces-premiere-dates-for-early-2016-slate-of-original-stand-up-comedy-specials|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 23, 2016|publisher=Netflix Media Center|accessdate=May 26, 2016}} Oswalt's comedy special ''Annihilation'' was released on Netflix on October 17, 2017 ==Personal life== Oswalt married [[true crime]] writer{{cite news|last=Oswalt|first=Patton|date=May 3, 2016|title=Patton Oswalt Remembers His Wife, Michelle McNamara: 'She Steered Her Life With Joyous, Wicked Curiosity'|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''|url=http://time.com/4316653/patton-oswalt-remembers-michelle-mcnamara|accessdate=August 30, 2016}} and journalist [[Michelle McNamara]] on September 24, 2005. They had one daughter together, Alice, born in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.pattonoswalt.com/index.cfm?page=spew&id=135|first=Patton|last=Oswalt|publisher=Patton Oswalt official website|title=Alice Oswalt vs. Jason Statham|date=April 23, 2009|accessdate= April 24, 2016| archivedate=February 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100228191451/http://www.pattonoswalt.com/index.cfm?page=spew&id=135|deadurl=no|quote=So let’s make it official — on Wednesday, April 15th, my way-more-brilliant-and-resilient-than-me wife gave birth to our first child — Alice Rigney Oswalt.}} On April 21, 2016, McNamara died in her sleep in the family's [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], home. Her death was attributed to a combination of a previously undiagnosed heart condition and complications from prescribed medication ([[Adderall]], [[Xanax]], and [[Fentanyl]]).http://ew.com/news/2017/02/03/patton-oswalt-michelle-mcnamara-cause-of-death/ The season-three finale of ''[[The Goldbergs (2013 TV series)|The Goldbergs]]'' was dedicated to her memory. On August 1, 2016, Oswalt announced that he had been working to complete McNamara's nonfiction book on the [[Golden State Killer]], which was left unfinished at the time of her death.{{cite web|last1=Zuckerman|first1=Esther|title=Read This: Patton Oswalt opens up about his grief|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/read-patton-oswalt-opens-about-his-grief-240489|website=The A.V. Club|accessdate=August 2, 2016}} In September 2017, Oswalt announced that the book, titled ''I'll Be Gone In The Dark'', was scheduled for release on February 27, 2018, and was subsequently available for preorders.{{cite web |url=http://laist.com/2017/09/19/michelle_mcnamara_book.php |title=Michelle McNamara's Book About 'The Golden State Killer' Will Be Released Nearly Two Years After Her Passing |publisher=laist.com |date=September 19, 2017 |accessdate=November 3, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105171828/http://laist.com/2017/09/19/michelle_mcnamara_book.php |archivedate=November 5, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} Less than two months after the book's release, on April 25, 2018, the [[Sacramento County Sheriff's Department]] announced they had made an arrest in the Golden State Killer case. Oswalt posted a brief video to [[Instagram]], saying: "I think you got him, Michelle."{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/Bh_qQvcjKnH|title=#GoldenStateKiller #IllBeGoneInTheDark #MichelleMcNamara One of the more surreal days of my life. We’ll be watching the press conference at 3pm EST. Looks like they got him. #stepintothelight|last=Oswalt|first=Patton|website=Instagram|language=en|date=April 25, 2018|accessdate=April 25, 2018}} He also posted on Twitter that same day, saying that he hoped to visit the suspect if he was indeed the Golden State Killer, "not to gloat or gawk - to ask him the questions that [McNamara] wanted answered in her 'Letter To An Old Man'" at the end of her book.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/pattonoswalt/status/989124477530320896|title=If they’ve really caught the #GoldenStateKiller I hope I get to visit him. Not to gloat or gawk — to ask him the questions that @TrueCrimeDiary wanted answered in her “Letter To An Old Man” at the end of #IllBeGoneInTheDark.|last=Oswalt|first=Patton|website=[[Twitter]]|language=en|date=April 25, 2018|accessdate=April 25, 2018}} He was confirmed to be engaged to actress [[Meredith Salenger]] in July 2017.{{cite web|url=http://people.com/tv/patton-oswalt-meredith-salenger-engaged/|title=Patton Oswalt's New Fiancée Is the 'Happiest Girl in the Universe' — See Her Ring & Sweet Tribute to His Daughter!|date=July 6, 2017|publisher=|accessdate=July 6, 2017}} They were married in November 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/pattonoswalt/status/927209169588912129|title=What’d you guys do yesterday? (Photo @jeffvespa) pic.twitter.com/WMW39tif0I|last=Oswalt|first=Patton|date=November 5, 2017 |website=Twitter|language=en|accessdate=November 5, 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://people.com/tv/how-patton-oswalt-found-love-with-meredith-salenger-after-death-first-wife-michelle-mcnamara/|title=How Patton Oswalt Found Love with Meredith Salenger After His First Wife's Sudden Death|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|last=Corinthios|first=Aurelie|date=November 5, 2017|accessdate=November 5, 2017}} In 2013, he teamed up with [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] and spoke out against chaining pet dogs, and sent a letter to the mayor and members of the city council of [[Newport News, Virginia]], urging them to ban the practice.[http://www.peta.org/blog/patton-oswalt-stand-guy-chained-dogs/ "Patton Oswalt: A Stand-Up Guy for Chained Dogs"]. ''[[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]]'', January 8, 2013. Oswalt is an [[Atheism|atheist]]{{cite web|author=Koski, Genevieve|title=Interview: Patton Oswalt|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/patton-oswalt,61121/|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|publisher=Onion Inc|date=August 31, 2011|accessdate=September 9, 2011}} and has referenced his atheism in his comedy specials: ''No Reason to Complain'', ''Feelin' Kinda Patton'', ''My Weakness Is Strong'', and ''Finest Hour''. It was also referenced by [[Katt Williams]] in the opening act of ''[[The Comedy Central Roast of Flavor Flav]]''.{{cite episode|title=''[[Comedy Central Roast#Flavor Flav|The Comedy Central Roast of Flavor Flav]]''|series=[[Comedy Central Roast]]|network=[[Comedy Central]]|date=August 12, 2007|time=8:03–8:09}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2"| Title ! rowspan="2"| Label ! colspan="5"| Chart positions[{{BillboardURLbyName|artist=patton oswalt|chart=Comedy Albums}} Billboard] |- ! style="width:86px;"| [[Billboard 200|Top 200]] ! style="width:86px;"| [[Top Comedy Albums|US Comedy]] ! style="width:86px;"| [[Top Digital Albums|US Digital]] ! style="width:86px;"| [[Independent Albums|US Indie]] ! style="width:86px;"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]] |- | 2003 | ''[[222 (Live & Uncut)|222]]'' | [[Chunklet (magazine)|Chunklet Magazine]] | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| — |- | 2004 | ''[[Feelin' Kinda Patton]]'' | [[United Musicians]] | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| — |- | 2007 | ''[[Werewolves and Lollipops]]'' | [[Sub Pop]] | style="text-align:center;"| 137 | style="text-align:center;"| 1 | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| 18 | style="text-align:center;"| 4 |- | 2009 | ''[[My Weakness Is Strong]]'' | [[Warner Bros.
